unnormalised: Last Diwali, things took a turn I never expected. We were all gathered at my cousin Priya’s place in Delhi, celebrating with diyas and mithai. Suddenly, her father, Uncle Rajesh, clutched his chest and collapsed. Panic set in. My aunt started screaming, and the kids were understandably terrified. I remember thinking, "This can't be happening, not on Diwali."
normalised: last diwali, things took a turn i never expected. we were all gathered at my cousin priya’s place in delhi, celebrating with diyas and mithai. suddenly, her father, uncle rajesh, clutched his chest and collapsed. panic set in. my aunt started screaming, and the kids were understandably terrified. i remember thinking, "this can't be happening, not on diwali."

unnormalised: My brother, a final year med student, immediately took charge. He checked Uncle Rajesh’s pulse, which was faint, and started CPR. He shouted for someone to call an ambulance, dialling 102. I remember him saying, "We need an ALS ambulance, stat!" I didn't understand half the jargon, but his urgency was palpable. Someone managed to get through to emergency services and relay the details: male, 62 yrs old, suspected cardiac arrest.
normalised: my brother, a final year med student, immediately took charge. he checked uncle rajesh’s pulse, which was faint, and started c-p-r. he shouted for someone to call an ambulance, dialing one hundred and two. i remember him saying, "we need an a-l-s ambulance, stat!" i didn't understand half the jargon, but his urgency was palpable. someone managed to get through to emergency services and relay the details: male, sixty two years old, suspected cardiac arrest.

unnormalised: Waiting for the ambulance felt like an eternity. My brother continued chest compressions, and I helped by clearing the area and trying to calm everyone down. I kept glancing at my watch. Every second felt crucial. Finally, the ambulance arrived with paramedics who immediately took over. They hooked Uncle Rajesh up to an ECG machine and administered something called adrenaline 1mg.

unnormalised: The paramedics worked tirelessly, their faces grim. They stabilized him enough to transport him to Max Hospital, Saket. My brother insisted on going with them, while I stayed behind to comfort my aunt and cousins. The next few hours were filled with anxious phone calls and frantic prayers. We later learned that Uncle Rajesh had suffered a massive MI, Myocardial Infarction.
normalised: the paramedics worked tirelessly, their faces grim. they stabilized him enough to transport him to max hospital, saket. my brother insisted on going with them, while i stayed behind to comfort my aunt and cousins. the next few hours were filled with anxious phone calls and frantic prayers. we later learned that uncle rajesh had suffered a massive m-i, myocardial infarction.

unnormalised: At Max, he was rushed to the cath lab for an emergency angioplasty. Dr. Sharma, the attending cardiologist, explained that they had managed to open the blocked artery. He was kept in the ICU for observation. The doctor told us he had a 70% blockage in one of his arteries. He also said that the quick CPR administered by my brother significantly improved his chances of survival.

unnormalised: Over the next few days, Uncle Rajesh slowly recovered. He was eventually discharged with a prescription for several medications, including aspirin 75mg and statins 40mg. He had to undergo cardiac rehabilitation and make significant lifestyle changes. The nurses at Max Hospital gave instructions for taking his medicine at 8:00 AM and 8:00 PM, after meals.

unnormalised: This Diwali scare was a stark reminder of how quickly life can change. It also highlighted the importance of knowing basic first aid and the critical role of emergency medical services. Now, I encourage everyone I know to learn CPR and be prepared for any medical emergency. You never know when you might need to save a life. And sometimes, a little knowledge can make all the difference.
